#Text=CHAPTER 9 .
#Text=Our Relations and Theirs

#Text=What I ’m trying to show here is that with these women the whole relationship of life counted in a glad , eager growing-up to join the ranks of workers in the line best loved ; a deep , tender reverence for one ’s own mother -- too deep for them to speak of freely -- and beyond that , the whole , free , wide range of sisterhood , the splendid service of the country , and friendships .
#Text=To these women we came , filled with the ideas , convictions , traditions , of our culture , and undertook to rouse in them the emotions which -- to us -- seemed proper .

#Text=However much , or little , of true sex-feeling there was between us , it phrased itself in their minds in terms of friendship , the one purely personal love they knew , and of ultimate parentage .
#Text=Visibly we were not mothers , nor children , nor compatriots ; so , if they loved us , we must be friends .
#Text=That we should pair off together in our courting days was natural to them ; that we three should remain much together , as they did themselves , was also natural .
#Text=We had as yet no work , so we hung about them in their forest tasks ; that was natural , too .
#Text=But when we began to talk about each couple having “ homes ” of our own , they could not understand it .
#Text=“ Our work takes us all around the country , ” explained Celis .
#Text=“ We cannot live in one place all the time . ”
#Text=“ We are together now , ” urged Alima , looking proudly at Terry ’s stalwart nearness .
#Text=( This was one of the times when they were “ on , ” though presently “ off ” again . )
#Text=“ It ’s not the same thing at all , ” he insisted .
#Text=“ A man wants a home of his own , with his wife and family in it . ”
#Text=“ Staying in it ?
#Text=All the time ? ” asked Ellador .
#Text=“ Not imprisoned , surely ! ”
#Text=“ Of course not ! Living there -- naturally , ” he answered .
#Text=“ What does she do there -- all the time ? ”
#Text=Alima demanded .
#Text=“ What is her work ? ”
#Text=Then Terry patiently explained again that our women did not work -- with reservations .
#Text=“ But what do they do -- if they have no work ? ” she persisted .
#Text=“ They take care of the home -- and the children . ”
#Text=“ At the same time ? ” asked Ellador .
#Text=“ Why yes .
#Text=The children play about , and the mother has charge of it all .
#Text=There are servants , of course . ”
#Text=It seemed so obvious , so natural to Terry , that he always grew impatient ; but the girls were honestly anxious to understand .
#Text=“ How many children do your women have ? ”
#Text=Alima had her notebook out now , and a rather firm set of lip .
#Text=Terry began to dodge .
#Text=“ There is no set number , my dear , ” he explained .
#Text=“ Some have more , some have less . ”
#Text=“ Some have none at all , ” I put in mischievously .

#Text=They pounced on this admission and soon wrung from us the general fact that those women who had the most children had the least servants , and those who had the most servants had the least children .
#Text=“ There ! ” triumphed Alima .
#Text=“ One or two or no children , and three or four servants .
#Text=Now what do those women DO ? ”
#Text=We explained as best we might .
#Text=We talked of “ social duties , ” disingenuously banking on their not interpreting the words as we did ; we talked of hospitality , entertainment , and various “ interests . ”
#Text=All the time we knew that to these large-minded women whose whole mental outlook was so collective , the limitations of a wholly personal life were inconceivable .
#Text=“ We cannot really understand it , ”
#Text=Ellador concluded .
#Text=“ We are only half a people .
#Text=We have our woman-ways and they have their man-ways and their both-ways .
#Text=We have worked out a system of living which is , of course , limited .
#Text=They must have a broader , richer , better one .
#Text=I should like to see it . ”
#Text=“ You shall , dearest , ” I whispered .
#Text=“ There ’s nothing to smoke , ” complained Terry .
#Text=He was in the midst of a prolonged quarrel with Alima , and needed a sedative .
#Text=“ There ’s nothing to drink .
#Text=These blessed women have no pleasant vices .
#Text=I wish we could get out of here ! ”
#Text=This wish was vain .
#Text=We were always under a certain degree of watchfulness .

#Text=When Terry burst forth to tramp the streets at night he always found a “ Colonel ” here or there ; and when , on an occasion of fierce though temporary despair , he had plunged to the cliff edge with some vague view to escape , he found several of them close by .
#Text=We were free -- but there was a string to it .
#Text=“ They ’ve no unpleasant ones , either , ”
#Text=Jeff reminded him .
#Text=“ Wish they had ! ” Terry persisted .
#Text=“ They ’ve neither the vices of men , nor the virtues of women -- they ’re neuters ! ”
#Text=“ You know better than that .
#Text=Do n’t talk nonsense , ” said I , severely .
#Text=I was thinking of Ellador ’s eyes when they gave me a certain look , a look she did not at all realize .
#Text=Jeff was equally incensed .
#Text=“ I do n’t know what ‘ virtues of women ’ you miss .
#Text=Seems to me they have all of them . ”
#Text=“ They ’ve no modesty , ” snapped Terry .
#Text=“ No patience , no submissiveness , none of that natural yielding which is woman ’s greatest charm . ”
#Text=I shook my head pityingly .
#Text=“ Go and apologize and make friends again , Terry .
#Text=You ’ve got a grouch , that ’s all .
#Text=These women have the virtue of humanity , with less of its faults than any folks I ever saw .
#Text=As for patience -- they ’d have pitched us over the cliffs the first day we lit among ‘ em , if they had n’t that . ”
#Text=“ There are no -- distractions , ” he grumbled .
#Text=“ Nowhere a man can go and cut loose a bit .
#Text=It ’s an everlasting parlor and nursery . ”
